title: Judgment on Jerusalem
shortSummary: Jeremiah 5 presents a solemn indictment of Jerusalem's moral and spiritual corruption, highlighting the absence of justice and truth among its people and leaders. The chapter warns of impending judgment through foreign invasion due to their persistent rebellion against God and false trust in empty prophets.
timeline: c. 627-586 BC - Late Kingdom of Judah before Babylonian exile

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet delivering God's message of judgment and calling for repentance in Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: The People of Jerusalem
keyCharacters.description: The inhabitants of Jerusalem who are accused of injustice, idolatry, and rebellion against God.

keyCharacters.name: The Leaders of Judah
keyCharacters.description: The great men and rulers who have knowledge of God's ways but have broken His covenant and failed to lead righteously.

keyCharacters.name: False Prophets
keyCharacters.description: Those who prophesy falsely, misleading the people and supporting the corrupt religious system.

definitions.definition: One who administers justice fairly and upholds God's standards of righteousness.
Relapses into sin or rebellion after having turned to God.
A symbol of submission and obedience to God's covenant and authority.
A metaphor describing the foreign invaders as deadly and ready to strike, like an open grave ready to receive the dead.
False prophecy refers to messages claimed to be from God but are deceptive and contrary to His truth.

outline.heading: Search for Justice and Truth
outline.description: God commands a search for even one righteous person in Jerusalem who practices justice and seeks truth, but none are found, highlighting the city's spiritual poverty and rebellion.

outline.heading: Consequences of Rebellion
outline.description: God declares that because of their many transgressions and idolatry, foreign predators symbolized as lions and wolves will bring destruction upon Jerusalem.

outline.heading: Judgment Announced: Foreign Invasion
outline.description: God reveals He will send a mighty, foreign nation to punish Israel and Judah, consuming their resources and cities, yet He will not utterly destroy them, preserving a remnant.

outline.heading: Call to Hear and Understand
outline.description: Jeremiah exhorts the people to listen despite their foolishness and rebellion, reminding them of God's sovereign power over nature and the consequences of their sins withholding blessings.

outline.heading: Corruption Among the People and Leaders
outline.description: The chapter condemns the wicked men who exploit others, prosper through injustice, and fail to defend the vulnerable, provoking God's judgment.

outline.heading: False Prophets and Priests
outline.description: The chapter closes with a denunciation of false prophets and corrupt priests who deceive the people, who love the lies, setting the stage for inevitable judgment.

application: Seek to live justly and pursue truth in all areas of life, reflecting God's character in personal and communal conduct.
Beware of hardening your heart against correction and resist the temptation to trust in false assurances rather than God's word.
Recognize the seriousness of idolatry and spiritual unfaithfulness, and repent promptly to avoid the consequences of divine discipline.
Test all teaching and prophecy against Scripture to avoid being led astray by false teachers.

keyVerses.text: Run ye to and fro through the streets of Jerusalem, and see now, and know, and seek in the broad places thereof, if ye can find a man, if there be any that executeth judgment, that seeketh the truth; and I will pardon it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores God's desire for justice and truth as the basis for mercy, highlighting the rarity of righteousness in Jerusalem.

keyVerses.text: Wherefore thus saith the LORD God of hosts, Because ye speak this word, behold, I will make my words in thy mouth fire, and this people wood, and it shall devour them.
keyVerses.significance: God declares that His prophetic word will be a consuming fire against the peopleâ€™s rebellion, emphasizing the power and judgment inherent in His message.

keyVerses.text: Shall I not visit for these things? saith the LORD: shall not my soul be avenged on such a nation as this?
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God's righteous judgment against injustice and corruption, reminding believers of His holy standards.

keyVerses.text: The prophets prophesy falsely, and the priests bear rule by their means; and my people love to have it so: and what will ye do in the end thereof?
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the danger of false teaching and the people's complicity in accepting lies, warning of the consequences of rejecting God's truth.
